{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3491774,"name":"Harrison","username":"hjmcphail76","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hjmcphail76/{size}/234713_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T18:08:39.345Z","cooked":"

I have an idea my team would like to try and I need some input from the experience of others. We are thinking making a laser cut 1/16in backing for the wood, and then it would have 90 degree bent flanges that mount to the drivebase. We recently discovered Cleco fasteners (and love them) and wanted to see if they could be used to secure bumpers to the frame. We think it could be a better alternative to a wing nut (the usual choice).

Any concerns with this?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T18:08:39.345Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":133.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483409,"topic_slug":"interesting-bumper-mounting-idea","display_username":"Harrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57833,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/interesting-bumper-mounting-idea/483409/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3491811,"name":"","username":"DunaganM","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c4cdca/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T18:35:26.083Z","cooked":"

I know of quite a few teams that have tried this, clecos can be quite good at getting you through that one next match, but as a long-term fastener they don’t work well. They bend under impact which makes them hard to remove, nullifying the gain you get by using them, and they quickly chew up the holes you put them in over time, which can result in them coming loose at the worst times. Overall I would not recommend them for bumper mounting, though it might be workable if you have extra features to isolate the clecos from impact forces.

@hjmcphail76 if you’re suggesting using 1/16 plywood as the only backing for the foam, and if you’re not backing the 1/16 plywood completely with anything else for the full 4.5 inch height (i.e. such that the 1/16 ply is merely “ceremonial”) then that definitely won’t survive a single match.

I think OP was referring to 1/16 Al or steel backing the normal plywood, with tabs bent from the metal backing to provide mounting features. Clarification would be good though.

We used 1/4" clecos in 2022 and 2023 to hold the bumpers in place.

They work, but we ran into issues with the clecos and holes in the frame rail wearing out. We wound up adding thin steel plates on top of the frame rail to help keep the hole intact, but still had to deal with worn out clecos popping out randomly.

We moved away from them last year and were very happy with our new system, so we will not be going back.

image1134×730 85.4 KB

You might consider using spring-loaded pins like McMaster-Carr instead of Clecos, and having them go through both sides of the frame. That requires semi-accurate holes, but also allows you to have a flange on both the top and bottom of the frame.

If you are looking for suggestions by far the most robust and fastest bumper mounting I’ve ever come across is the following method:

Parts:
partially threaded screws: McMaster-Carr
fender washers: McMaster-Carr
Nylocks: McMaster-Carr
Jam Nuts: McMaster-Carr
Southco latches: https://shop.southco.com/en_us/r4-05-20-405-10

(links are for reference only and better prices may be available elsewhere)

The bumper system is assembled according to the drawing below. (at least four latches on a set of full halo bumpers)

Bumper changes are no more than 20 seconds (toolless) since the latches are lever actuated and they continued to work perfectly smoothly even after a season of very hard hits.

image1920×864 134 KB

This was a post I made a few years ago. It made bumpers a toolless change.

Bumper Attachment Successful Options Technical Discussion
We use these: McMaster-Carr Super easy to spin on and off and they are solid. They go through holes in the bumper plate and connect to pem nuts that are mounted on the frame. Bumpers look like this. You can see the knob in the lower left and upper right: [bumper%20closeup] We mount the bumpers to a carrier plate that gets mounted to the robot.
